Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Situation2: A life-support device in the intensive care unit is flashing critical fault codes.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to leave for the hospital. It was Mia, her voice trembling, telling me her father had passed away unexpectedly. She needed me—her words barely holding together, asking if I could come over. My heart twisted; I wanted nothing more than to hold her, to be the anchor she needed in this storm. But as I hung up, my pager blared. The hospital’s ICU had a life-support machine flashing critical fault codes. I was the only technician on call, and every second counted for the patient relying on that machine. My mind raced with images: Mia alone in her grief, and a patient’s life hanging by a thread. Both needed me, both right now. I felt split in two, the weight of expectation pressing from both sides, my chest tight with helplessness as I stood frozen, keys in hand, unable to move.
